tn.text: Job begins to answer Zophar's accusations.
"Allow me" or "Be patient with me"
"you can continue mocking me." Job is using sarcasm to imply that his friends would ignore what he would say and continue to mock him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
Job continues speaking to his friends.

tn.ref: As for me, is my complaint to a person? Why should I not be impatient?
tn.text: Job uses questions to emphasize that he thinks it is fair for him to complain to God. AT: "I am not complaining to a person. I have the right to be impatient" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: lay your hand upon your mouth
tn.text: "cover your mouth with your hand."  Possible meanings are that 1) this is a response to being astonished. AT: "cover your mouth with your hand" or 2) this is a symbol that the person will not speak. AT: "do not say anything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_symaction]])
"fear causes my body to tremble" or "I shake with fear"
Job continues speaking to his friends.

tn.ref: Why do wicked people continue to live, become old, and grow mighty in power?
tn.text: Job uses this question to show that his friends are wrong to think evil men always suffer. AT: "Wicked people indeed continue to live, become old, and become wealthier." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: Their descendants are established with them in their sight ... their offspring are established before their eyes
tn.text: This two clauses mean the same thing and emphasize that this is true. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: in their sight ... before their eyes
tn.text: These phrases mean the same thing because "eyes" refers to sight. Wicked people get to watch their descendants grow strong and wealthy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here "houses" refers to the family members that lives in them. AT: "Their families" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
This refers to God's punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Job continues speaking to his friends.

tn.ref: does not lose her calf prematurely
tn.text: "she does not miscarry" or "her calf is born healthy and strong"
Job compares these children to lambs to emphasize that they run, play, and are happy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
a musical instrument with a head like a drum that can be hit and with pieces of metal around the side that sound when the instrument is shaken (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_unknown]])
Job continues speaking with his friends.
"their lifetime"

tn.ref: they go down quietly to Sheol
tn.text: This is a polite way of saying that they die. AT: "they die peacefully" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This refers to how God wants people to behave.

tn.ref: What is the Almighty, that we should worship him? What advantage would we get if we prayed to him?
tn.text: The wicked people use these questions to mock God. AT: "We do not believe that this Almighty God is worthy of our worship. He can do nothing for us." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Job continues speaking to his friends.

tn.ref: See, is not their prosperity in their own hands?
tn.text: Here "hands" refers to their power or control. Job uses this question to challenge his friends. AT: "Look, these wicked people claim that they make themselves prosper!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: How often is it ... their calamity comes upon them?
tn.text: Job uses this question to emphasize that it seems to him that God does not punish the wicked very often. AT: "It is not often ... their calamity comes upon them." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the lamp of wicked people is put out
tn.text: Job compares extinguishing the lamp to a person dying. This can be stated in active form. AT: "that God causes them to die suddenly" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Job compares the life of the wicked to a lamp that is burning. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: How often does it happen ... in his anger?
tn.text: Job uses this second question to emphasize that it seems to him that God does not punish the wicked very often. AT: "It is not often ... in his anger." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: How often is it ... the storm carries away?
tn.text: Job uses this third question to emphasize that it seems to him that God does not punish the wicked very often. AT: "It is not often ... the storm carries away?" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: they become like stubble before the wind or like chaff that the storm carries away
tn.text: The death of the wicked is spoken of as if they were worthless less chaff and stubble that blows away. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God takes them away like the wind blows away the chaff" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Job continues speaking to his friends.
These words are added by most versions in order to make it clear that the Job is quoting his friends in the next statement.

tn.ref: God lays up one's guilt for his children to pay
tn.text: Guilt is spoken of as something that can be stored for later use. Here "to pay" refers to punishment for sin. AT: "God keeps a record of a person's sins, then he punishes the person's children for his wicked deeds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Job now begins to state his own opinion. It may be helpful to state this explicitly. AT: "But I say, 'Let him pay it himself'" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "eyes" refers to the person. AT: "Let him see" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: let him drink of the wrath of the Almighty
tn.text: Here the wrath of God is spoken of as if it a drink that a person can taste, and tasting is a metonymy for experiencing the drink. Job wants the wicked person to experience God's punishment. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: For what does he care about his family after him when the number of his months is cut off?
tn.text: Job uses this question to show that the punishing the evil man's children is not effective. This can be stated in active form. AT: "For the wicked man does not care about his family after he has died!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: the number of his months is cut off
tn.text: This is a polite way of saying that he dies. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
this refers to the length of his life
Job continues speaking to his friends.

tn.ref: Can anyone teach God knowledge since he judges even those who are high?
tn.text: Job asks this question to emphasize that God knows everything. AT: "Obviously, no one can teach anything to God since he even judges those in heaven." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Possible meanings are 1) "those who are in heaven" (UDB) or 2) "powerful people."

tn.ref: One man dies in his full strength
tn.text: Job contrasts this man who dies in health and peace to the man who dies in sorrow and pain in [[:en:bible:notes:job:21:25|21:25]]. You can make this explicit. AT: "If there are two men, one may die in his full strength" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: His body is full of milk
tn.text: Both of these mean that the person is very healthy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: His body is full of milk ... the marrow of his bones is moistened and in good health
tn.text: Both of these phrases mean that the person is very healthy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: His body is full of milk
tn.text: The word for "milk" may mean "fat." Either rendering means he is well-fed. AT: "His body if full of fat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: the marrow of his bones is moistened and in good health
tn.text: This idiom means his body is youthful and healthy. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Job continues speaking to his friends.
Job contrasts this man to the man who dies in peace in [[:en:bible:notes:job:21:22|21:23]].

Here sorrow is spoken of as if it tasted bitter, and "soul" refers to the whole man. AT: "with anger and resentment" or "after living a sad life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This can be stated in positive form. AT: "has experienced only bad things"

tn.ref: They lie down alike in the dust
tn.text: This is a polite way to say that they died. AT: "They both die and people bury them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Worms are associated with decay of dead bodies. AT: "the worms in the dirt eat their dead bodies"
Job continues speaking to his friends.
Job uses this phrase to call attention to the statement that follows. AT: "Behold"

tn.ref: Where now is the house of the prince? Where is the tent in which the wicked man once lived?
tn.text: Job believes his friends will ask these question to scold him. Both questions mean the same thing. AT: "See, the house of the evil ruler is gone. The tent of the wicked man has disappeared." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
Job continues speaking to his friends.

tn.ref: Have you never asked traveling people? Do you not know the evidence they can tell ... from the day of wrath?
tn.text: Job uses these questions to rebuke his friends for not learning from people who travel. AT: "You should listen to those who have traveled to distant places. Even they will tell you ... from the day of wrath." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: the wicked man is kept from the day of calamity ... he is led away from the day of wrath
tn.text: These phrase mean the same thing. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God spares the wicked person when he brings disaster on a place" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Job continues speaking to his friends.

tn.ref: Who will condemn the wicked man's way to his face?
tn.text: Job uses this question to contradict his friends' belief that the wicked are always judged. AT: "No one condemns the wicked man to his face." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This means no one will go directly to the wicked person and condemn him personally. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Who will repay him for what he has done?
tn.text: Job uses this question to contradict his friends' belief that the wicked are always judged. AT: "No one repays him for the bad things that he has done." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "people will carry him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: The clods of the valley will be sweet to him
tn.text: Job imagines that the dead person will even enjoy the dirt that is put on him. This means the wicked person will even have a good death and a nice burial after a fulfilling life. "Clods" refer to the earth that covers the grave. AT: "He will enjoy being covered with the dirt of the valley" or "He will enjoy being buried in the dirt of the valley" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: all people will follow after him, as there were innumerable people before him
tn.text: Job emphasizes that a large crowd of people will be in the funeral procession of this imaginary wicked man to honor him. AT: "a huge number of people go to the grave site; some go in front of the procession and some come behind" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_hypo]])
This concludes Job's speech to his friends.

tn.ref: How then do you comfort me with nonsense, since in your answers there is nothing but falsehood?
tn.text: Job uses a question to scold his friends. AT: "You cannot comfort me with nonsense. All of your answers are false." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
